awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Van der Waals Epitaxial Heterostructures: Beyond 2D Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Technical: This CAREER project is to study the synthesis of large-area, uniform, and high-quality two-dimensional (2D) van der Waals epitaxial heterostructures with controlled band structures. The 2D heterostructure consists of multiple monolayers of dissimilar transition metal dichalcogenide materials (TMDC) epitaxially stacked together. Unlike other approaches for the synthesis of 2D TMDC materials, this project explores a unique, self-limiting chemical vapor deposition process that the principal investigator has developed. The project involves synergistic efforts in the development of controlled scalable synthesis of 2D TMDC heterostructures and in the understanding of correlation between the physical features and band structures of the heterostructures. It starts with studies of the fundamentals of the self-limiting growth mechanism, followed by the development of techniques for the controlled scalable synthesis based on the fundamental understanding. It also involves the development of a Raman-based characterization metrology tool to provide high-throughput characterizations for the compositions and structures of the heterostructures. Additionally, the principal investigator plans to examine the correlation between the band structures and physical features of the heterostructures. 
 
Non-technical: This project addresses fundamental challenges in an emerging cutting-edge area of materials science. The success of this project can provide capabilities to rationally design a new class of artificial materials with compositions and structures tuned at the atomic scale. It lays down the groundwork for the principal investigator to pursue his career goal that aims to investigate new physical phenomena of 2D heterostructures and to explore these materials for applications in the field of optoelectronics. The new material platform can open up unexplored opportunities for a wide range of fields including information technology, solar energy harvesting, light emission diodes, and flexible electronic/photonic devices. The research component of this project is integrated into multifaceted educational and outreach activities that aim to inspire students (high school, undergraduate, and graduate) to pursue careers in the STEM disciplines and aim to enhance the secondary school and university curricula in materials science. In addition to providing research training for students at both undergraduate and graduate levels, the education plan includes mentoring high-school students to participate in pre-college scientific competitions and guest lectures in high schools' AP chemistry classes.

Intellectual merit:

Two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenide (TMDC) materials have been widely considered as a promising material platform for next-generation integrated circuits and optoelectronic devices. However, there are many unanswered fundamental scientific questions about 2D TMDC materials, which has imposed significant restriction for the device development of this materials.   In this project, we have addressed many of them  ranging from synthesis, transfer, and fundamental properties.  More specifically, these include:

  1. Developed a unique surface-energy-assisted-transfer (SEAT) techniques for the perfect transfer of wafer-scale 2D TMDC materials with no observable polymer residue, wrinkles, and cracks. (Fig.1)
  2. Demonstrated the dynamics of interlayer exciton transfer in epitaxial and non-epitaxial 2D TMDC heterostructures, such as WS2/MoS2, is similar. (Fig.2)
  3. Significantly enhanced the light absorption efficiency of 2D TMDC materials by orders of magnitude for either narrow-band incidence or broadband incidence such as solar light. (Fig.3)
  4. Elucidated much new fundamental understanding for the PL and exciton  dynamics of 2D TMDC materials.  These include effect of substrates, effect of intercalated anions, and exciton-exciton annihilations (Fig.4, Fig. 5, and Fig. 6).
  5. Provided unambiguous studies for the thermal conductivity of 2D TMDC materials, and also developed capabilities to electrically control the interfacial thermal conductivity with 2D TMDC materials (unpublished yet).

These results significantly advance the fundamental understanding for 2D TMDC materials, and provide useful guidance for the rational design of functional devices with these materials. Additionally, the fundamental understanding for 2D TMDC materials can also be applied to many other 2D materials.

 

Broader Impact:

The impact of this project is beyond the field of 2D materials.   Many of the results can impact other important technical fields.  For instance, the development of atomically thin light superabsorbers can pave the way for the development of cost-effective, light-weight, and high-performance solar conversion devices.   The demonstration of electrical control of interfacial thermal conduction has the potential to revolutize the field of thermal management.  

The impact of the project is augmented by the integration of education and outreach effort. 2 postdocs, 7 graduate students, numerous undergraduate students and high school students from my group participate this project in different ways.  Other than that,  the project also involves 2 postdocs/research scientists and 5 graduate students from collaborator groups.  The postdocs and students involved have received well round training in a variety of fields, including synthesis, electrical/optical characterization, device fabrications, and also theoretical calculation.  The training well prepares them for career development in the STEM fields. 

The research results have been widely disseminated.  This include:

  1. Paper: 6 published papers at highly respected journals, 2 manuscripts under review, and 1 under preparation.  
  2. Patent: 1 provisional patent filed, 1 technical disclosure , and 1 provisional patent to be file.
  3. Technical transfer: the patent filed has already been licensed to our industrial parter, Atomic Inc.
  4. Presentations: The results have been reported in conferences and seminars tens of times.
  5. Dissertation: The results of this project consist of important parts of 4 PhD dissertations in my group.
  6. Media coverage: Sour works have received media coverage from tens of professional and public media worldwide.
